summary: This document is an email chain from October 2020 between an Assistant U.S. Attorney and FBI personnel regarding the coordination of discovery evidence in the Epstein case. It involves requests to match CART evidence numbers with FBI barcode numbers for various seized electronic devices from searches in New York and the Virgin Islands.

persons.name: M, (USANYS)
persons.context: The prosecutor from the Southern District of New York requesting evidence information and coordinating discovery to meet a November deadline.

persons.name: (NY) (FBI)
persons.role: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.context: FBI forensic examiner in New York coordinating the Computer Analysis Response Team (CART) evidence, providing barcode information and managing access to seized devices.

persons.name: (NYPD)
persons.context: Copied on the email chain regarding evidence discovery coordination.

persons.name: Special Agent FBI New York Field Office
persons.context: Introduced the forensic examiner to the prosecutor to facilitate discovery questions related to child exploitation and human trafficking.

connections.description: Prosecutor and FBI forensic examiner coordinating on evidence discovery for the case, with the prosecutor making requests and the examiner providing technical evidence information.

connections.person1: Special Agent FBI New York Field Office
connections.description: FBI agent facilitated the connection between the prosecutor and the forensic examiner for discovery coordination.
Both law enforcement entities copied on evidence discovery communications.

events.title: Final Discovery Deadline
events.description: The prosecutor references a final discovery deadline of November 9th, 2020, indicating time pressure to complete evidence review and production.

events.title: Evidence Coordination Emails
events.description: Series of emails discussing the matching of CART evidence numbers to FBI barcode numbers for devices seized from New York and Virgin Islands searches.

keyFacts: The document reveals ongoing evidence coordination in late 2020 between the U.S. Attorney's Office and the FBI regarding electronic devices seized in the Epstein investigation.
Multiple electronic devices were seized from searches in New York and the Virgin Islands, including hard drives, iMacs, thumb drives, and servers.
The prosecutor was working against a November 9, 2020, discovery deadline and needed to match CART evidence numbers with FBI barcode/18 numbers for proper evidence tracking.
The FBI forensic examiner noted challenges with evidence recovery due to COVID-19 impacts and the need to physically visit evidence control in the Bronx.
The email chain is subject to a protective order, indicating the sensitive nature of the evidence and discovery process.
